item.title: Covid: Boris Johnson urges caution as England schools to reopen
item.description: The PM says the return of schools in England on Monday is the "first step" towards "normality".

item.title: Covid: Nurses condemn 'fundamentally flawed' PPE rules
item.description: The existing recommendations are based on out-of-date evidence, the Royal College of Nursing says.

item.title: Covid-19: Vaccine offers for all those aged 56 or over
item.description: People in the age group are being invited to book their first vaccine from this week.

item.title: George Floyd: Why is the trial so important?
item.description: A US police officer is accused of killing a black man last year. Here's why the world is watching.

item.title: Covid-19: First roadmap date approaches, and 'fundamentally flawed' PPE
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Sunday morning.

item.title: Covid: Dalai Lama urges others to get vaccinated as he receives first shot
item.description: The Tibetan spiritual leader urges others to "take this injection" as he gets the AstraZeneca jab.

item.title: Parents worry about lost learning as schools return
item.description: Parents are confident about children returning to school but worry about catching up, says survey.

item.title: Pope Francis visits regions of Iraq once held by Islamic State
item.description: The Roman Catholic leader visits Mosul, the former stronghold of the Islamic State group.

item.title: Murder investigation over missing woman Bennylyn Burke and two-year-old daughter
item.description: Bennylyn Burke and two children had been missing from South Gloucestershire since 17 February.

item.title: Hunger Games salute: The symbol of protest against Asia’s military regimes
item.description: The three finger gesture has become a defining symbol of demonstrations in Myanmar and Thailand.

item.title: Ikea boss warns tariffs will lead to higher prices
item.description: Jesper Brodin, who heads the firm, says he fears global trade tensions will mean customers must pay more.

item.title: The Papers: Queen 'won't watch' interview, and EU 'ill will'
item.description: Royal news continues to dominate the papers ahead of Harry and Meghan's Oprah Winfrey interview.

item.title: Losing a twin: 'With great love, comes great loss’
item.description: The sister of a girl who died following a school bus crash speaks about how she copes with her grief.

item.title: US bombers deployed to Arctic skies from Norway base
item.description: The US has deployed long-range bomber planes to Norway, in a move seen as a message to Russia.

item.title: The women of Egypt's Arab Spring
item.description: Ten years ago, Egyptians took to the streets calling for the overthrow of President Hosni Mubarak

item.title: In pictures: Thousands attend LGBT Mardi Gras in Sydney
item.description: Thousands gathered for the event, which was scaled back over Covid-19 safety concerns.

item.title: Stormont signer's children passing on their skills
item.description: Stormont signer Kristina Sinclair's children use sign language despite not having hearing difficulties.

item.title: Katy Sprague: The family piecing together an 'avoidable murder'
item.description: Katy Sprague's family believe if their concerns had been addressed she would still be alive today.

item.title: Kings of Leon on Mick Jagger, lockdown hair and writing songs on bar napkins
item.description: The rock band discuss Mick Jagger, lockdown haircuts and how their lyrics start on bar mats.

item.title: Raya and the Last Dragon: Disney's new heroine representing 670 million people
item.description: After almost 90 years of animated films, Disney has finally ventured into South East Asia.

item.title: UK Royal Family: Who is in it and how does it work?
item.description: Here are some of the things you need to know about the British royals.

item.title: What's your pension invested in?
item.description: While pension pots are going green, how easy is it to dump investments in tobacco or gambling?

item.title: Back to school: 'I'm ready for a coffee in peace'
item.description: As children in England return to school on Monday, parents have mixed emotions.

item.title: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe: The five years separated from her family
item.description: The day before Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe is due for release, her husband talks of his hopes and fears.

item.title: Gerrard says Rangers 'have been to hell and back', with club on verge of title
item.description: Rangers have "been to hell and back over the past 10 years", says manager Steven Gerrard, with the club one point from the Scottish Premiership title.

item.title: Leicester grab late winner at Brighton to go second
item.description: Daniel Amartey scores an 87th-minute winner as Leicester come from behind to beat Brighton and boost their bid for Champions League qualification.

item.title: 'I wondered how many sunny days I would see again' - Ferguson discusses brain haemorrhage
item.description: Former Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson opens up about his 2018 brain haemorrhage in new film.

item.title: Former European champions Saracens beaten by Pirates in Championship opener
item.description: Former Premiership and European champions Saracens lose 25-17 in their Championship opener at Cornish Pirates.

item.title: England complete T20 series clean sweep over New Zealand
item.description: England thrash New Zealand by 32 runs to complete a clean sweep in their three-match Twenty20 series.

item.title: Blachowicz defeats Adesanya at UFC 259 as Nunes wins again
item.description: UFC light-heavyweight champion Jan Blachowicz sees off middleweight challenger Israel Adesanya at UFC 259, where Amanda Nunes also wins again.

item.title: Tottenham Hotspur: Daniel Levy prepares to celebrate 20 years as Tottenham's chairman
item.description: As Tottenham Hotspur chairman Daniel Levy prepares to celebrate 20 years in charge of one of England's biggest clubs, BBC Sport speaks to those who know him well.

item.title: Covid: How will testing work in schools?
item.description: All students in England can return to classrooms from 8 March, but how will Covid testing work?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 21 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The prime minister has announced a plan for how the lockdown will be lifted in England.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Budget 2021: How much will it cost the UK and how will we pay?
item.description: The pandemic is costing the government hundreds of billions of pounds. Where will it all come from?

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Covid lockdown: Why Magna Carta won’t exempt you from the rules
item.description: People are turning to tactics that misinterpret outdated law to avoid coronavirus regulations.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford University-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday in the UK or travel abroad?
item.description: The government has unveiled its plans for unlocking UK restrictions, including holiday travel.

item.title: 'Vaccine passports': Will I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The government is reviewing whether venues can ask for proof of vaccination or a negative test.

item.title: Lockdown Learning: What educational resources are on TV, iPlayer and online?
item.description: As schools remain closed to most pupils, the BBC is offering a wealth of educational material.

item.title: Covid variant: What happens when coronavirus mutates?
item.description: New Covid-19 variants keep appearing – and their mutations are very different to the comic book kind.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: The 'LitterCam' that's watching you
item.description: AI software can now match footage of motorists throwing rubbish with their car's number plate and issue an automatic fine .

item.title: Our Lives: Will my hometown survive this lockdown?
item.description: An ongoing Covid-19 study has shown how the North of England was hit harder than the rest of the country.

item.title: Then and now: A 'megadrought' in California
item.description: See how extreme weather has affected an vital reservoir in California.

item.title: Budget 2021: Bedford's High Street hoping for 'booming summer trade'
item.description: A £5bn scheme to help town centres is announced - but will it be enough to help a "struggling" town?

item.title: Tintern 'secret' medieval tunnel system found by accident
item.description: A team of electrical technicians made the discovery while moving an electrical pole in Monmouthshire.
